title: Measuring the Ocean
caption: The Ocean Observatories Initiative (OOI) has hundreds of instruments collecting data every minute of every day from seven locations (arrays) throughout the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans. Here we are looking at data from the Coastal Endurance location in the Temperate Pacific Ocean (red box).

title: The ocean off of the Pacific Northwest
caption: The Coastal Endurance location is in the ocean off of Oregon and Washington. There are many instruments at this location. Data in this activity were collected from the Central Washington Line (red box).

title: What does it look like underwater?
caption: This drawing represents where the different instruments are attached to cables running from the surface down to the seafloor (i.e., a mooring) along the Central Washington Line. Data in this activity were collected from instruments on the Shelf Surface Mooring (D, red box).

title: What is on a Mooring?
caption: The Near Surface Instrument Frame (red box) at 7m below the water surface is where the data for this activity were collected at the Shelf Surface Mooring. Many instruments, each collecting different oceanographic variable data, are included but data for this activity were collected using a CTD instrument.

title: How does a CTD work?
caption: The CTD measures and records conductivity, temperature, and pressure as water flows through the instrument. Then scientists can calculate the salinity, density, and depth of the water. This CTD, a Sea-Bird - SBE 16plusV2, stores data (recovered data), and communicates some of the data in real time (telemetered data).
